In addition, we ran Monte Carlo simulations (Muthén & Muthén, 2002) to determine the required sample size of the most complex measurement model (i.e., 3 to 6 indicators per latent factor; 2 latent factors; factor loadings ≥ .50; factor correlation ≥ .35). A sample size of 190 is needed to achieve a 95% power.

Evaluation of model fit according to Schermelleh-Engel et al. (2003): χ 2 goodness-of-fit statistic, CFI ≥ .95, RMSEA ≤ .08, and SRMR ≤ .10. Comparing different models: Satorra-Bentler-scaled χ 2 difference test (i.e., nonsignificance indicates equal model fit).
paradigms measure a common underlying habitization process (RQ3) and which paradigms are most strongly associated with real-life habitual behavior (RQ4).

div.head: H3.2:
div.p: The data of all six habit paradigms and the three working memory tasks will fit a twodimensional measurement model (i.e., each a latent factor for habitization and for working memory) significantly better than a one-dimensional measurement model (discriminant validity).

A two-dimensional measurement model is interpreted as evidence that habitization is (partly) independent of working memory. Otherwise: Habit paradigms and working memory task measure the same underlying process.

div.head: Ethics information and participant compensation
div.p: Participants will be informed about the study procedure, their right to withdraw their consent at any time, data security and the use of their anonymized data (including public data sharing upon study completion). They will then give written informed consent. The study was approved by the local ethics committee (Human Subjects Committee of the Faculty of Economics, Business Administration, and Information Technology; OEC IRB # 2020-072).

The participants will receive CHF 20 (at the time of testing, CHF 1 ~ 1.10 US$ ~ 0.90€) per hour of testing for each session. In addition, they receive money from their performance in the monetarily reinforced tasks (Reward Pairs task: CHF 0.50-4.50 each day plus CHF 1-9 for the test phase on the last day; Contingency Degradation task: CHF 0-6.84 each day; Outcome Devaluation taskLuque : CHF 0.15-5.00 each day; 2-step task: CHF 10-13).

This amounts to a pay-out of CHF 194-272 with an expected average payment of CHF 235 according to pilot data. Participants who withdraw from the study will be compensated with CHF 25 for each day they attended fully and CHF 10 for every hour started on days they did not complete.

div.head: Design
div.p: The study includes one week of data collection. It starts with an invitation email with a sign-up link, followed by participants receiving a study description and giving informed consent. They then fill in a sociodemographic questionnaire, the German versions of the Stöber, 1999Stöber, , 2001). In addition, they will complete a version of a sequential

Markov decision paradigm assessing model-free and model-based behavior (2-Step; Kool et al., 2016). Within one week before the training of the habit tasks begins, participants will have to fill in these questionnaires and perform the 2-Step task online to reduce the amount of time spent in the lab. The COHS, SRHI, and HTQ are used as real-life habit measures to validate the experimental measures of habitual behavior. The handedness score of the EHI will be used in analyses of RTs to control for generally faster responses with the preferred hand. The SDS-17 will be used to control for tendencies to respond in a socially desirable manner in the test phase of the Unrewarded Habit task if necessary. The sociodemographic information will only be used to characterize our sample.

As the study procedure is quite extensive, we will apply a planned-missing design (Graham et al., 2006;Little et al., 2014;Rhemtulla & Hancock, 2016). In these designs, the complete sample is randomly split into several subgroups. Each subgroup performs one set of experimental tasks and questionnaires, which is common to all participants, and leaves out one task. For each participant, the left-out task is random. Hence, the missing data is missing completely at random (MCAR) and can be imputed for analyses across tasks on the basis of the data acquired from each participant (see Analysis plan). In our case, we will randomly assign participants to one of two subgroups. Each subgroup performs all questionnaires and tasks except for one (either the outcome devaluation taskLuque (Luque et al., 2020) or the contingency degradation (Vaghi et al., 2019) task). Therefore, the required assessment time for each participant is reduced, decreasing their individual workload.

The first on-site assessment will start with three working memory tasks (Lewandowsky et al., 2010), which take approximately 25min to perform, followed by the first outcome devaluation task (45min; Pool et al., 2021;Tricomi et al., 2009). Next, all participants will perform the Unrewarded Habit task (21min) and Reward Pairs task (18min) in random order. These two tasks will be repeated daily until and including the fifth day (see Table S1 for an overview of the study procedure). In addition, each participant will perform one of the two remaining tasks, that is, either the contingency degradation task (35min; Vaghi et al., 2019) or the second outcome devaluation paradigm (35min; Luque et al., 2017Luque et al., , 2020.
Training of the contingency degradation or the second outcome devaluation task will start on the second day of on-site assessment and will proceed daily until and including the fifth day.

A short break of 1-3 min is included between the tasks. On the fifth day, the training phases of the tasks are followed or replaced by the respective test phases. The fifth day closes with a debriefing questionnaire asking for choice strategies during the test phases of the habit paradigms and paying out the participants. The first session will last around 110min, the second to fourth session around 65min, the fifth session around 85min, and the online assessment prior to the first assessment around 90min.

The tasks will be trained over several days (Table S1) with order randomized across participants but constant within participants to control for effects of motivation changes within a training session. All tasks and questionnaires will be applied in German. For the following description of the materials, the wording was translated into English.

div.head: Selection of stimuli for Reward Pairs and Unrewarded Habit Task
div.p: Change in subjective value ratings is an outcome variable of interest for the Reward Pairs and the Unrewarded Habits tasks. We use pre-training ratings also to select stimuli for these tasks. Specifically, participants rate a set of 15 geometric shapes (Reward Pairs task) and 15 abstract figures (Unrewarded Habit task) twice before the first training session. They are asked "How do you like the symbol on this box?" and use a slider to respond on a continuous visual analogue scale ranging from 0 to 100 with the verbal anchor points of "not at all" (0), "neutral" (50), and "extremely well" (100). The eight (Reward Pairs task) or four (Unrewarded Habit task) individually most neutrally rated stimuli (averaged over the two ratings per stimulus) are used for the experiment. Using an individual set of stimuli for the tasks serves two purposes. First, it controls for pre-experiment preferences between the given stimuli. Second, it limits stimulus-specific effects (Clark, 1973;Judd et al., 2012). We control for remaining stimulus-specific variance (Baayen et al., 2008) by using a random-effects model (see Analysis plan).

div.head: Reward Pairs Task
div.p: The first task is an instrumental learning paradigm, in which we manipulate the reward value of stimuli and their choice frequency during training independently from each other.
Each trial shows one stimulus on the left side of the screen and one on the right side ( Figure 1A). Crucially, the task comprises pairs of stimuli, not presented together during training,

where both stimuli have the same objective value but one of them is presented often with a less valuable stimulus and therefore chosen more often during training. Conversely, the other stimulus of the pair is presented primarily with a more valuable stimulus and therefore chosen less often during training. When the two same-reward stimuli are presented together during test, we examine whether the difference in choice frequency during training has an effect on choice during test. Participants have a response window of 800ms to choose one of them by pressing either "X" or "M" on the keyboard. A purple frame indicates the chosen stimulus for 500ms, before both stimuli with their respective outcomes appear for 1000ms. A purple frame indicates the chosen stimulus and the reward associated with it. The subsequent inter-trial interval (ITI; 1000-3000ms) is exponentially jittered and the remainder of the response window is added to it to hold the length of each trial constant. Training takes place on each of five consecutive days with 160 trials per session.

There are eight stimuli in the Reward Pairs task. Each stimulus deterministically yields a reward of 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9 points ( Figure 1B). Participants learn the contingencies between stimuli and rewards through trial-and-error. To facilitate learning and reduce uncertainty about the rewards associated with rarely chosen stimuli, participants receive feedback about the outcomes of both the chosen and unchosen stimulus after each decision in the training phase (but not in the test phase, see below). Delivering rewards deterministically instead of stochastically should increase the stability of the task environment and thereby facilitate the development of habits.

For three stimulus pairs, the stimuli yield the same amount of reward (3, 5, or 7 points), and these same-reward pairs never appear together during training. For each samereward pair, reward maximizing decision makers will choose one stimulus more often than the other because during training, one stimulus is frequently paired with a stimulus providing two points less or a stimulus providing two points more. Specifically, each stimulus is shown 40 times in one training session -either 10 times with a less valuable stimulus and 30 times with a more valuable stimulus or vice versa (see Table S4 for a list of all stimulus pairings during one training session). In consequence, stimuli within pairs are chosen either more or less frequently as long as participants adhere to the instruction to maximize points earned. For example, within say the 5 points pair, one stimulus is paired 30 times with a stimulus worth 3 points and 10 times with a stimulus worth 7 points and the other way around for the other stimulus ( Figure 1B). Hence, for the three intermediate reward levels (i.e., 3, 5, and 7 points), there is one stimulus chosen frequently during training and the other chosen rarely, which disentangles stimulus value and choice frequency. Stimulus-to-position assignments will be matched for left and right positions across stimuli, such that the number of choices at each position is similar. In total, participants can earn between 640 and 960 points in one training session, and they are instructed that one trial will be randomly selected each day and the reward associated with their choice added to the final pay-out with 1 point being worth CHF 0.5. Participants are instructed to keep on maximizing the points earned and that two trials of the test phase will be chosen randomly at the end and paid out, with 1 point worth CHF 0.5.

After the first rating, participants complete a free-choice phase without outcome presentation for both tasks. Participants are instructed to choose the stimuli they like better, and that their choices in this phase have no consequences but serve to familiarize them with the test situation and to experience the short decision time windows that will be used in the real experiments. Choices in this phase reveal pre-experiment preferences between the stimuli, which can be existent even if the stimuli have been rated similarly before (Chen & Risen, 2010). Note that we use the most neutrally rated stimuli per participant, but these do not have to be exactly neutral. Participants are not excluded from the study for not rating enough stimuli in the neutral middle region of the rating scale, but the analyses of choice data will be corrected for pre-experiment stimulus preferences including both the rating and the choice in the free-choice phase. A second rating of all (i.e., used and unused) stimuli (also twice per stimulus) after the test phase on the last day allows us to test whether choice frequency during training changed the subjective value of stimuli. Furthermore, participants will rate 10 additional abstract stimuli at the beginning and end of the study, which will not be used in any task for any participant. We will use these to estimate of how reliable stimulus ratings are in general.

After the test phase and the second stimulus rating, participants complete debriefing questions. These questions concern the reward value of each stimulus and how confident participants are about their answers. Most participants of the pilot study revealed perfect knowledge about the reward value for each stimulus (see Supplementary Information for a more detailed analysis of pilot data). This finding is a prerequisite to interpret differences in choice frequency of stimuli within the same reward level as resulting from different previous choice proportions during training rather than from larger uncertainty about the value of less frequently chosen stimuli. Therefore, we will exclude participants from our analyses with less than 50% accuracy in the debriefing question about stimulus-reward associations. To associate behavior in the Reward Pairs task to behavior in other tasks and answer

RQs 3 and 4, we will compute an individual score of frequency-based habitual choice from the test phase (Reward Pairs choice score). This procedure is similar to scores computed from choices in sequential decision and outcome devaluation paradigms (e.g., Linnebank et al., 2018;Luque et al., 2020;Nebe et al., 2018). The score captures the propensity of participants to choose stimuli during test which they chose more (rather than less) frequently during training, for each of the same-reward pairs. Reward Pairs choice scores closer to the maximum value of 1 reflect stronger preference for the more frequently chosen stimuli, scores around zero correspond to no preference, and scores closer to the minimum value of -1 represent a preference for more rarely chosen stimuli.
Reward Pairs choice score =

Similar to the choice data, we will compute an individual score of frequency-based habit-related RT acceleration (Reward Pairs RT score), corresponding to the decrease in median RTs when choosing a previously frequently chosen stimulus relative to a previously less frequently chosen stimulus, for each same-reward pair. Reward Pairs RT scores closer to the maximum value of 0.8 represent relative RT acceleration for stimuli that participants chose more frequently in training, scores around zero correspond to little effect of choice frequency during training, and scores closer to the minimum value of -0.8 represent faster responses for stimuli that participants chose more rarely in training.

We will compute an individual score of frequency-based rating changes (Reward Pairs rating score) corresponding to the average increase in liking ratings for previously more frequently chosen stimuli relative to previously less frequently chosen stimuli. Reward Pairs rating scores closer to the maximum value of represent stronger increases in liking ratings for previously more frequently chosen stimuli, scores around zero signify no differential rating changes between more and less frequently chosen stimuli, and scores closer to the minimum value of -100 represent greater increases in ratings for previously more rarely chosen stimuli.
Reward Pairs rating score =

In addition to these three measures and the learning rate parameter of the choice kernel in the computational model, we will calculate the magnitude of the effect of training for the choices and RTs. To do so, we calculate the Reward Pairs choice score and Reward Pairs RT score for the first test phase on Day 1 and subtract this from the respective scores of the test phase on the last day and divide the result by two. Therefore, there are six scores of participants' behavior potentially reflecting habitization, which will enter the factor analyses and structural equation models of Research Questions 3 and 4.

div.head: Unrewarded Habit Task
div.p: This task studies the effect of differences in behavioral frequency in the absence of external reinforcement during training on unrewarded free choice during test. At the beginning of each training trial of this instructed-choice paradigm ( Figure 1C), two stimuli appear on the screen. After a uniformly jittered interval of 150-300ms, one of the stimuli receives a blue frame indicating that participants should select this stimulus as quickly and accurately as possible by pressing either "F" or "J" on the keyboard. Participants have 500ms

to respond. Time pressure supposedly facilitates habit development (Luque et al., 2020). If they press a button before the onset of the blue frame, the phrase "Pushed too early" appears for 1300ms, no further response in this trial is recorded, and the trial counts as missing. If participants fail to respond within 500ms, the words "Too slow" appear for 800ms and the trial counts as missing. If participants respond within the given time window, a brown frame appears around both the chosen and unchosen stimulus for 800ms. Thus, all stimuli are presented with the same duration and participants receive feedback that their response was recorded, but the feedback is the same for either action, limiting outcome-related learning to a minimum. The ITI is exponentially jittered between 1000 and 3000ms and includes also the remainder of the response time window.

There are two stimulus pairs in the Unrewarded Habit task, which differ in the instructed choice proportions. In one pair, one stimulus is indicated to be chosen in 80% of the training trials, the other stimulus in the remaining 20% of training trials. In the other pair, In addition, we will compute an individual score of frequency-based habit-related RT acceleration (Unrewarded Habit RT scores) corresponding to a decrease in median RTs when choosing the previously more frequently chosen stimulus relative to the less frequently chosen stimulus. More positive Unrewarded Habit RT scores represent faster responses for the previously more frequently chosen stimulus, scores around zero correspond to little effect of choice frequency during training, and more negative scores reflect faster responses for the more rarely chosen stimulus.
Unrewarded Habit RT score =

Finally, we will compute an individual score of frequency-based habit-related rating changes (Unrewarded Habit rating score) capturing the increase in the liking rating of the previously more frequently chosen stimulus relative to the less frequently chosen stimulus.

More positive Unrewarded Habit rating scores represent stronger increases in liking ratings for the previously more frequently chosen stimulus, scores around zero correspond to no differential rating changes between more and less frequently chosen stimuli, and more negative scores reflect stronger increases in ratings for the more rarely chosen stimulus.
Unrewarded Habit rating score =
As with the Reward Pairs task, we will compute the magnitude of the effect of training for choices and RTs and use them in the analyses of Research Questions 3 and 4.

div.head: Outcome Devaluation Task Tricomi
div.p: As a benchmark paradigm of habit induction, the first outcome devaluation task (Tricomi et al., 2009) uses actual snack foods as outcomes and a specific satiation procedure for devaluation (for a multi-lab replication study: (Pool et al., 2021); for the MATLAB code:

https://github.com/evapool/MULTILAB_HABIT.) We will closely follow the procedure described by Pool and colleagues (2021). In this paradigm, participants first rate their level of hunger on a 10-point Likert scale from "very full" (1) to "very hungry" (10), then taste and rate the pleasantness of six different snacks (three salty and three savory) on an 11-point Likert scale from "very unpleasant" (-5) to "very pleasant" (5). The favorite snack in each of the two categories is selected as outcomes in the task. A free-operant training phase follows, consisting of two sessions. This amount of training is equivalent to the moderate training group of Pool and colleagues (2021), who have shown no statistically significant difference in devaluation sensitivity between a participant group with two sessions in one day and a group with twelve training sessions equally distributed over three consecutive days. They concluded that most participants developed habitual responding within two training sessions and found no evidence to support the hypothesis that longer training makes participants more habitual in this task. Thus, we include this task with two training sessions only on the first day of the study.

Each of the two free-operant training sessions consists of twelve task and eight rest blocks. One of three fractal images and a schematic indicating the response button appears on the screen for the whole duration of a block (20 or 40s). Participants can press the response button self-paced. If they press the button, they may receive a reward (either the sweet or savory snack, which is presented on the screen for 1000ms) or nothing, in which case a grey circle is presented for 50ms on the screen. Reward delivery follows a variable-interval schedule with a mean of 10s (VI-10s). The VI-10s is implemented such that in each second there is a 10% chance that a button press within this second would deliver a reward. Thus, a reward becomes available on average every ten seconds and delivery is triggered by the first response after it becomes available. Each of the three fractals is associated with one of the two selected snacks or the rest block, in which participants are instructed not to respond. The order of blocks is pseudo-randomized within each participant so that no block type (sweet snack, savory snack, rest) occurs more than twice in a row.

After the second training session on the first day of assessment, one of the snacks is devalued by satiation (sweet or savory, balanced across participants). To induce satiation, the participants are presented with a bowl of the respective snack, which has been weighed beforehand. Participants can then eat as much as they want (and the amount will serve as a control variable). Next, participants again rate their level of hunger and the pleasantness of the two snacks used in the training sessions.

The devaluation procedure is followed by the test phase, which consists of six task blocks (three for each of the two snacks) and three rest blocks, presented in pseudorandomized order. Exactly as in the training sessions, the previously trained fractals and response schematic are presented but no reward is delivered. However, participants are instructed that they are nevertheless accumulating the respective snack outcomes associated with the presented fractal. Each block has a duration of 20s. Each response is followed by presentation of a grey circle for 50ms, but without food (i.e., in extinction).

To compute the behavioral measure of interest for this task, we calculate the average number of button presses per second in the second training session (i.e., six blocks per snack, pre devaluation) and in the test phase (i.e., three blocks per snack; post devaluation). If participants do not adapt their level of responding in the test session compared to the training for the devalued snack outcome, behavior is defined to be habitual for this task. Thus, we calculate a "behavioral adaptation index" (BAI; Pool et al., 2021) We relate this index to behavior in the other tasks (RQ3) and to real-life habitual behavior (RQ4).

div.head: Outcome Devaluation Task Luque
div.p: A second previously published outcome devaluation task (Luque et al., 2017(Luque et al., , 2020 will provide another benchmark measure of habit. This paradigm (available at https://github.com/DavLuke/MATLAB-Habits-Overtraining-Exp3) operationalizes habits as RT switch costs without affecting choice (Luque et al., 2020). Participants learn to associate different visual stimuli and button presses with different outcomes. The task includes four types of stimuli in the form of cookies, two responses in the form of selecting one of two aliens, and three outcomes in the form of diamonds. In each trial, one of the cookies appears and participants give it to one of the two aliens by button presses in order to receive one of three diamonds, which are worth five, ten, or 100 points, respectively. Aliens differ in which type of diamond they trade for the different cookies. Thus, participants learn which cookiealien combination (i.e., stimulus-response association) leads to the best outcomes. Interleaved consumption trials, in which participants choose between different diamonds, test whether participants have learned the different outcome values.

Participants will perform eight training blocks with 52 trials each (12 trials with each of four cookie stimuli and four consumption trials) each day on four consecutive days starting on the second day of the study (Table S1). In test phases on the first and last training day, specific outcome types will be devalued. Specifically, at the beginning of each test block, one type of diamond is announced to yield no points in this block and participants have to react by switching their responses to a diamond that was worth fewer points during training but is now the only valuable outcome. These response switches supposedly lead to a conflict between perseverative habitual and flexible goal-directed behavioral control. Such conflict is not necessarily evident in the choices (even though the animal literature clearly shows that habitization affects choices; Balleine & O'Doherty, 2010) but associated with an increase in RTs in switch trials (Luque et al., 2020). Hence, the RT switch cost is the outcome measure of interest in this task. As an increase in habit strength occurred only under time pressure in previous studies, we will use the time-constrained task versions of Experiments 2a and 2b of Luque and colleagues (2020) and expand the training from three to four days to increase the probability of inducing habits not only in RT but also in choice.

For the analyses regarding RQs 3 and 4, we will calculate two scores similar to the original study (Luque et al., 2020). First, the difference of the proportion of responses leading to the devalued outcome in the test phase minus the same responses during the last training block before devaluation separately for the high and low valued outcome.
div.formula: DVAL choice score = ( ℎ | , ℎ ) − ( ℎ | , ℎ )
div.p: This results in the DVAL choice score, which ranges from -1 to 1, with -1 reflecting perfect goal-directed switching after devaluation, 0 corresponding to habitual perseveration of the now-devalued response, and (the very unlikely score of) 1 indicating that participants did not choose the valued outcome during training but did so after devaluation. We will include the choice score to test whether additional training facilitates habitual behavior not only with regard to RT but also choice in this task.

Second, the DVAL RT switch costs in test trials will be calculated as the median RTs in switch trials after devaluation (separately for previously high and low valued outcome trials) minus the median RTs in the respective trials in the last training block before devaluation.

Switch trials refer to the trials in which participants successfully switched away from the devalued to the non-devalued stimulus during the test phase. RTs in switch trials are contrasted with the RTs for choosing the same stimulus before its devaluation. For example, in trials comparing a stimulus worth five points to a stimulus worth 100 points, the median RT of choosing the 100-point stimulus before devaluation would be subtracted from the median RT of switching to the five-point stimulus after devaluating the 100-point stimulus.
div.formula: DVAL RT switch cost = ( | ℎ − , ℎ ) − ( | , ℎ )
div.p: The DVAL RT switch costs are stronger if responses to devalued stimuli are slower during test than training. These costs presumably arise from the cognitive conflict of having to overcome habitual choice tendencies and switch to the previously less valued choice.
As with the Reward Pairs and Unrewarded Habit tasks, we will compute the magnitude of the effect of training for choices and RT switch costs to use them in the analyses of Research Questions 3 and 4.

div.head: Contingency Degradation Task
div.p: We will use a modified version of the contingency degradation task designed by Vaghi and colleagues (2019) to capture the second criterion of the traditional habit definition. This free-operant task is presented in several 120s blocks. In each block, participants view a white triangle on the screen and are free to press the response key as often as they wish.

Unbeknownst to them, each 1s-bin is associated with a probability of monetary reward if the participant responded and a probability of reward if the participant did not respond during the bin. The contingency, i.e., the relation between the two probabilities varies between blocks but stays constant within each block. At the end of each block, participants are asked to rate on a visual analogue scale how causal they think their responses were for the reward to materialize. The scale ranges from -100 to 100 indicating the continuum from "Responses always prevented rewards" to "Responses always caused rewards".

In blocks with positive contingency, the probability of receiving a reward in each 1sbin if at least one response has been made (P(O|A)) is positive (e.g., constantly 60%), while the probability of receiving a reward without having made a response (P(O|~A)) is zero. In negative contingency blocks, the probability of receiving a reward upon having produced a response is zero and the probability of receiving it without having made a response is positive.

In blocks with degraded contingency, both the probability of receiving reward contingent on having produced a response and the probability of reward in the absence of a response are positive (but not necessarily of the same magnitude), that is, rewards can be caused by a response but might also appear without it. Behavior is deemed habitual in this task if participants with prior training on the positive contingency schedule do not adapt their response rates in blocks with degraded or negative contingency.

We use a modified version of the task that includes blocks with positive contingency of P(O|A)=0.6 and P(O|A)=0.3 (both block types having P(O|~A)=0; Table S3 for an overview of all block types and how often they will be presented on each assessment day).
The positive contingencies are varied between blocks to keep participants engaged in the task.
In addition, blocks with degraded contingencies will be interspersed. Training on this task will be done on each of four consecutive days from the second day of the study (Table S1).

The outcome measure of interest in this task is a ratio score of the number of responses in the (fully and partially) degraded blocks relative to the sum of responses in both the (fully and partially) degraded and contingent (non-degraded) blocks of the last day (Ersche et al., 2020;Vaghi et al., 2019). Thus, this variable is close to 0.5 if participants respond to a similar degree in both contingent and degraded blocks, reflecting habitual behavior, i.e., an insensitivity to changes in contingencies. The score is close to zero the more participants respond during the contingent blocks and the less they respond during degraded blocks, that is, if participants are highly sensitive to changes in action-outcome contingencies. Values between 0.5 and one correspond to more responses during degraded than contingent blocks, which may reflect misunderstanding of task instructions or lack of attention or motivation. In addition, the causal judgements at the end of each block will be used as an outcome measure of interest.

We will further compute the magnitude of the effect of training for the ratio score as with the previous tasks by subtracting the score of the first day of training from the score of last to use them in the analyses of Research Questions and 4.

div.head: Sequential Markov Decision Task (2-Step)
div.p: The sequential Markov decision task (Kool et al., 2016) uses model-free (as opposed to model-based) reinforcement learning to operationalize habitual (as opposed to goaldirected) behavioral control. This task version is freely available (https://github.com/wkool/tradeoffs) and takes into account several limitations (Akam et al., 2015;Kool et al., 2016Kool et al., , 2017 of the original task (Daw et al., 2011).

Participants start each trial in one of two possible states ( Figure S4). Each of these two initial states has the same representation of planet earth in the background but contains two different stimuli in the form of spaceships (i.e., spaceships A vs B in one initial state and spaceships C vs D in the other). Participants need to choose one of the two spaceships. This choice leads to a second state, in which participants face one of two aliens. The second state does not require a choice but only a press of the space bar in response to seeing the alien, which yields space treasure (if positive), antimatter (if negative), or nothing. These outcomes, representing points, vary according to a Gaussian random walk with a mean of zero points, a standard deviation of two points, and reflecting boundaries at the minimum of minus four and maximum of five points. Crucially, in each of the two initial states, one spaceship deterministically flies to one alien and the other spaceship to the other alien (i.e., spaceships A and C fly to alien 1 and spaceships B and D to alien 2). Thus, the two states are essentially equivalent. This feature is important to dissociate model-free from model-based control.

Model-based control "knows" about the equivalence because it represents the full state space including the transitions between states and can use the outcome in a specific second state to make inferences about the other initial state. In contrast, model-free control has no state representation and can guide choice only by the value of outcomes. Hence, model-free and model-based control make qualitatively different predictions about decisions when the initial state of the trial differs from the one on the previous trial.

div.head: Analysis of 2-
div.p: Step data is based on the computational model provided by Wouter Kool (https://github.com/wkool/tradeoffs) and the mfit toolbox for Matlab provided by Sam Gershman (https://github.com/sjgershm/mfit). This model combines model-free and modelbased reinforcement learning. The behavioral data of each participant is fit to this hybrid model, yielding an individual best-fitting estimate of all free parameters (α, β, λ, π, ρ, ω; Supplementary Information section 2.3 for details). For the present study, the ω parameter is the outcome measure of interest as it captures the relative weight of model-based and modelfree reinforcement learning in computing the subjective value of options to guide behavior.

For our analyses, we will invert this parameter so that larger values (closer to the maximum of 1) correspond to more model-free (i.e., presumed habitual) control and smaller values (closer to the minimum of 0) to more model-based control.

div.head: Working Memory Capacity Tasks
div.p: We will use three tasks of a working memory test battery (Lewandowsky et al., 2010) to control for the effects of cognitive abilities in our analyses of habitual behavior: numeric memory updating (NMU), spatial short-term memory (SSTM), and sentence span (SS). By using three different tasks assessing the two processes entailed in working memory (storage in the context of processing and relational integration) with two different content types (verbal, including numeric, and spatial) we aim to achieve a more construct-representative measure of working memory capacity. These three tasks have been shown to correlate highly with a construct-representative measure of working memory capacity (Lewandowsky et al., 2010) and, thus, can be considered as working memory marker tasks.

In the NMU task, participants have to memorize numbers and update them according to mathematical operations. Each trial starts with the presentation of a set of three, four or five frames. A number from one to nine then appears in each frame, one by one, for one second.

Next, arithmetic operations ranging from -7 to +7, excluding 0, can appear randomly in any frame. Participants have to memorize the result of the operation for each frame. After two to six updating operations, the trial ends, a question mark appears consecutively in each frame and participants have to type in the respective current digit for that particular frame. The outcome measure is the participant-specific total proportion of items recalled correctly, ranging from 0 to 1.
In the SSTM, participants have to memorize the position of several dots in a 10x10

grid. In each trial, two to six dots appear one by one for 900ms each with 100ms interstimulus interval. After presentation of the last dot, a cue prompts the participants to reproduce the relative pattern of dots, that is, the location relative to each other. Neither the exact absolute position of the individual dots in the grid nor the sequence of the dots matters.

Participants receive 2 points for an exact match, one point for recalling a dot with a deviation of one cell and zero points for higher deviations. The participant-specific total sum of points is divided by the maximum possible score to yield a proportion of correct answers ranging from 0 to 1 similar to the NMU task (see Lewandowsky et al., 2010, pp. 573f).

The SS task is a complex-span paradigm comprising a memory component and a secondary processing task (Lewandowsky et al., 2010). The present version of the task uses verbal material for both components. For the secondary processing component, participants read a sentence consisting of three to six words for 5s and have to judge and indicate within this time window whether this sentence is meaningful or not. Examples for a meaningful and meaningless sentence are "All bumblebees can fly." and "All birds live in the city.". After indicating the meaningfulness of a sentence, a consonant is presented on the screen for 1s before a 100ms inter-trial interval and the beginning of the next trial. Participants have to memorize the consonants shown in the order they have been presented and report them back after the end of the current list. Each list has a length of three to seven sentences and consonants. The task begins with three practice trials containing two, three, and four sentences and consonants, respectively. The outcome measure is the participant-specific total proportion of correctly recalled consonants (including the correct position in the list) ranging from 0 to 1 similar to the other working memory capacity tasks. Participants are instructed to categorize the meaningfulness of the sentences and report the memorized consonants as accurately as possible. Thus, they are not aware that only the correct reporting of consonants is used as a measure of their working memory capacity.

div.head: Questionnaires
div.p: All questionnaires will be performed by the participants online before the first training session. They will be programmed so as not to produce missing responses, that is, participants will not be allowed to proceed to the next page if an item has not been answered.

div.head: Self-Report Habit Index (SRHI)
div.p: The Self-Report Habit Index (SRHI; Thurn, 2014;Thurn et al., 2014;Verplanken & Orbell, 2003) is a self-report questionnaire used to measure the habit strength of real-life behaviors. These behaviors are freely definable (e.g., "Taking the car to go to work is something …" or "Drinking alcohol is something …") and participants complete twelve items (e.g., "I do frequently", "that makes me feel weird if I do not do it", or "I would find hard not to do") for each of them. We will assess the habit strength of eleven different real-life behaviors: brushing teeth, eating meat, having breakfast, drinking coffee, drinking alcohol, smoking, going to school/university/work by bike, going to school/university/work by bus/tram/train, doing sport/exercises, eating snacks/candy, and watching TV/online streaming services (items partly taken from Gardner et al., 2011Gardner et al., , 2012Rees et al., 2018). In line with previous research, we will use a 7-point Likert scale (i.e., from 0="disagree" to 6="agree").

The response for each item will be recoded so that higher numbers correspond to stronger habits. All twelve responses regarding a particular behavior will be summed up and divided by the maximum possible points (i.e., 72) to obtain a value between zero (lowest possible habit strength) and one (highest possible habit strength). These maximally eleven behaviorspecific scores are then averaged to a final habit strength score. Because we focus on habits as frequently expressed behavioral routines, we will consider only those of the eleven behaviorspecific scores for the calculation of the final mean habit score for which participants have indicated that they show the behavior frequently (i.e., response category three or higher in response to the item "I do frequently"). If not at least three of the eleven behaviors are performed frequently, then the final habit strength score is coded as missing to ensure that the final score represents general habitual behavior.

div.head: Creature of Habit Scale (COHS)
div.p: The Creature of Habit Scale (COHS; Ersche et al., 2017;Overmeyer et al., 2020) consists of 27 items comprising a statement about behavioral routines, automatic responses, and habits. Answers are given on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1="strongly disagree" to 5="strongly agree". Example items are "I like to park my car or bike always in the same place", "I tend to do things in the same order every morning (e.g., get up, go to the toilet, have a coffee…)", and "I tend to like routine". The final scores for the two distinct subscales of automaticity (11 items) and routine (16 items) are calculated by averaging the respective item scores. Correlation between these subscales is rather low (r=.154; Ersche et al., 2017).
Therefore, they are not combined to an overall score but used as separate measures of habitual behavior.

div.head: Habitual Tendencies Questionnaires (HTQ)
div.p: The Habitual Tendencies Questionnaire (HTQ; Ramakrishnan et al., 2021) is an eleven-item self-report questionnaire assessing the subscales Compulsivity, Regularity, and Aversion to Novelty. Example items are "The same thoughts often keep going through my mind over and over again", "There is comfort in regularity", and "I look forward to new experiences" (reverse scored). Answers are given on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 0="strongly disagree" to 7="strongly agree". The final score in this questionnaire is the result of summing up the values of all eleven items. In addition, the scores of the three subscales are formed by summing up the four or three items belonging to each scale, respectively. Both the total score and the subscale scores will be used for further analyses.

div.head: Trier Inventory for Chronic Stress (TICS)
div.p: As previous research has indicated a link between habitual behavior and some measures of stress and anxiety (Friedel, 2017;Pool et al., 2021;Wirz et al., 2018), we will assess chronic stress, trait anxiety, and impulsiveness with established questionnaires and explore the associations between these measures and measures of habitual control. However, this is only a side issue for our study to allow future research to examine the relationships between stress and habit formation more closely.

The Trier Inventory for Chronic Stress (TICS; Petrowski et al., 2012;Schulz et al., 2004) is a self-report questionnaire containing 57 items, which assesses chronic stress on nine factors: work overload, social overload, pressure to perform, work discontent, excessive demands at work, lack of social recognition, social tension, social isolation, and chronic worrying. Example items are "I have too many tasks to perform.", "Although I try, I do not fulfill my duties as I should.", and "I have unnecessary conflicts with others." Responses are

given to the question, how often participants have experienced an item or felt that way in the last three months, on a 5-point Likert scale with verbal anchors for each point (0 = "never", 1 = "rarely", 2 = "sometimes", 3 = "often", 4 = "very often"). Based on the item-factor mapping reported by Petrowski and colleagues (2012), the raw item scores of each scale will be summed up to calculate the nine scale scores for further analyses.

div.head: State/Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI)
div.p: We will implement the trait version of the State/Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI; Spielberger et al., 1999). This version of the STAI consists of 20 items assessing general feelings of anxiousness, worry, and sadness. Example items are "I feel nervous and restless", "I feel like a failure", and "I feel inadequate". Responses to the items are given on a 4-point

Likert scale with verbal anchors for each point (1 = "almost never", 2 = "sometimes", 3 = "often", 4 = almost always"). Raw item scores are summed up to generate a trait anxiety score for further analyses.

div.head: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS-15)
div.p: The Barratt Impulsiveness Scale short form (BIS-15;Meule et al., 2011;Spinella, 2007) is a 15-item self-report questionnaire used to measure impulsive behavior. Answers are given on a 4-point Likert scale with verbal anchors (1 = "rarely/never", 2 = "occasionally", 3 = "often", 4 = "almost always/always"). Example items are "I act on impulse", "I say things without thinking", and "I plan tasks carefully". The items are grouped into three subscalesmotor, non-planning, and attentional impulsiveness -comprising five items each and a sum score of the raw item values for each subscale is calculated for further analyses.

div.head: Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (EHI)
div.p: The Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (EHI; Oldfield, 1971) is a questionnaire giving participants eight behavioral routines (e.g., brushing teeth, writing with a pen, or using scissors) and asking them which hand they prefer to use for performing these tasks. The answers are indicated on a 5-point Likert scale with verbal anchors of "always left", "usually left", "both equally", "usually right", and "always right". Answers are coded on an integer scale from 0 (corresponding to "always left") to 5 (corresponding to "always right"). Thus, sum scores close to the maximum (i.e., 40) represent strong right-handedness, while sum scores close to zero represent strong left-handedness.

div.head: Social Desirability Scale (SDS-17)
div.p: Social desirability is an answer tendency, which might influence choices during the test phase of the Unrewarded Habit task. In the test phase of this task, there is no obvious stimulus feature guiding choices, because the stimuli are not associated with reward and no information tells participants what to choose. Therefore, we could expect random choices or simple choice strategies like always choosing the left stimulus or alternating between stimuli in a pattern. Alternatively, participants could deduce for the test phase that the experimenters expect them to prefer the stimulus previously instructed to be selected more often. If a participant is likely to respond in a socially desirable manner, they might prefer this stimulus to supposedly satisfy the experimenter. For this reason, we include the Social Desirability Scale (SDS-17;Stöber, 1999Stöber, , 2001) in our assessment. This is a 16-item self-report questionnaire to measure social desirability in general. Answers are forced binary decisions between "yes" or "no". Example items are "I always stay friendly and courteous with other people, even when I am stressed out", "I occasionally speak badly of others behind their back", and "I take out my bad moods on others now and then". A mean score of all items with "yes" responses coded as 1 and "no" responses as 0 (and reversed for six items) is the outcome measure of this questionnaire. Higher scores indicate a stronger tendency to answer in a socially desirable manner. If this mean score will show a statistically significant correlation with the choices in the Unrewarded Pairs task, we will use it as a covariate in the analyses of hypothesis H2a to control for tendencies to answer in a socially desirable manner.

div.head: Sociodemographic Questionnaire
div.p: Participant age, gender, education level, socioeconomic status, and ethnicity will be assessed to characterize the sample.

div.head: Sampling plan
div.p: There are no previously published studies that examined related research questions, leaving us with no base for an estimation of the expected effect sizes and of the required sample size. Furthermore, the generalized linear mixed effects models (GLMMs) used to analyze the pilot data (see Supplementary Information) did not converge with the full random effects structure, because of the insufficient sample size, preventing us from using these analyses as basis for our power analyses. Therefore, we simulated data with an assumed effect size that would be of interest (Cohen's d=0.2 as a typical effect according to Gignac & Szodorai, 2016) and calculated an appropriate sample size to achieve 95% power for this effect size given our analytical approach. We simulated data based on the GLMMs used for the pilot data with the simr package (version 1.0.5; Green & MacLeod, 2016) in R (R Core Team, 2019). We added simulated participants to our pilot sample to reach a sample size of 200, then used subsamples of different size to calculate the observed power with the given sample size, resulting in a power curve for one fixed effect of the GLMM over a range of sample sizes. These analyses showed the strength of our mixed-effects within-subject design:

we need relatively small sample sizes to achieve adequate statistical power, because we model individual choices and RTs on a trial-by-trial level using more information than when using aggregated measures of behavior. For example, the simulation approach yielded a minimum sample size of 20 to achieve 98.20% (CI: 97.17%, 98.93%) power for the small effect of previous choice frequency in the Reward Pairs task. The same procedure for the GLMM of the choice frequencies during the test phase of the Unrewarded Habit task with a small effect of previous choice frequency yielded a minimum sample size of to achieve 96.10% (CI:
94.71%, 97.21%) power for this effect.

In the contingency degradation task, habitual behavior corresponds classically to the absence of an effect of the degradation on response rates. Thus, there is no effect size for this effect to base a power calculation on. However, Vaghi and colleagues (2019) found the hypothesized stronger habitual behavior in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder compared to control participants, with Cohen's d=0.912. If we were to replicate their effect, we would need a sample size of 66 to reach 95% power (t test, independent groups, α=.05, two-tailed; G*Power 3.1.9.2; Faul et al., 2009). A similar issue holds for outcome devaluation taskLuque, in which the absence of an effect of the devaluation indicates habitual choices.

Following the rationale for the contingency degradation task, if we were to replicate Luque and colleagues' (2019) effect (Cohen's d=0.789) of the amount of training on responding with 95% power, we would require a sample of 86 participants (t test, independent groups, α=.05, two-tailed; G*Power 3.1.9.2; Faul et al., 2009). Thus, a bigger concern for the required sample size is the correlational approach used in Research Questions 3 and 4.

Regarding the correlational analyses between different tasks measuring habitual behavior (Research Questions 3), we consider a correlation of r≥.5 and a well-fitting unidimensional measurement model as the criterion for a common habit process involved in all six tasks. Our reasoning is based on previous findings with regard to typical associations of different cognitive and behavioral tasks in individual differences research (e.g., Kretzschmar et al., 2016) as well as research on habitual behavior (Friedel et al., 2014;Gillan et al., 2015;Sjoerds et al., 2016). As there are no studies reporting correlations between self-reported habits in questionnaires and experimental data (Research Question 4), we ground our expectation of such a relation in previous research on the associations between test performance in cognitive tasks and the self-estimate of these cognitive abilities (r=.34-.55;von Stumm, 2014), and relations between SRHI scores and real-life behavior in a meta-analysis (r=.46;Gardner et al., 2011). However, in order to have a more conservative estimate of the required sample size, we decreased the expected size of the correlation to r=.3 (corresponding to a large effect according to Gignac & Szodorai, 2016) between experimental and real-life habitual behavior. Thus, to achieve 95% power, we require a sample size between 190 (RQ3) and 200 (RQ4) participants based on Monte Carlos simulations and the theorized measurement und structural equation models (Muthén & Muthén, 2002; Table 1).

To account for possible dropout during the successive training sessions, we will increase the necessary sample size to 220 participants to be able to compensate up to 10% dropout (pilot study: 5.6%). As we will use a planned missing design (see the Design section), 110 participants will enter the analyses of outcome devaluation taskLuque and the contingency degradation task, respectively. For the analyses across tasks (Research Questions 3 and 4), we will use multiple imputation of the missing data of each participant (van Buuren, 2018).

Hence, the sample size for these analyses will be 220. In addition, this sample size gives us sufficient statistical power (i.e., >99%) to identify a small effect (Cohen's d=0.2) in all (G)LMMs used in RQs 1 and 2.

Participants will be sampled from the database of the [masked for blinded peer review]. The behavioral lab allows for the testing of 36 participants simultaneously, but there might be a substantially lower cap of the number of participants allowed to be in the lab at the same time due to Covid-19-related hygiene and safety plans. If on-site testing will not be efficient, the experimental paradigms will be re-programmed for online testing (e.g., with

Prolific: www.prolific.co). Exclusion criteria are not having performed the online questionnaires and 2-Step at the beginning of the first training session. To be included in the study, participants must not have partaken in the pilot study, be capable of understanding the German language for task instructions, and have normal or corrected-to-normal vision.

Furthermore, we only include participants aged 18 to 40 years to avoid age effects and exclude participants with prior diagnosis of neurological or psychiatric disorders. If the study is implemented as an online study, all instructions and tasks will be translated to English and the inclusion criterion regarding language comprehension changed accordingly.

div.head: Analysis plan
div.p: For the analyses of RQs 1 and 2, we will use (G)LMMs (Baayen et al., 2008;Bates et al., 2015). These mixed-effects models have the advantage of enabling the combination of continuous and categorical responses and allowing to model heteroskedasticity (Baayen et al., 2008). Furthermore, these analyses aim to increase the precision of estimated group (fixed) effects by explicitly modelling the variance of the dependent variable associated with specific participants or items (random effects).

All (G)LMMs will initially be set up with the maximal random effects structure (Barr et al., 2013). That is, each fixed effect (main effects and interactions) will be included as a random effect with random intercept and slope nested in individual participants. In addition, the stimulus identity (i.e., the specific stimulus irrespective of the condition in which it is used) will be included as a random effect (intercept only) controlling for the used subset of the 15 stimuli rated at the beginning of the study. In case of convergence failures or singular model solutions with all appropriate optimizers allowed by the lmercontrol function (package lme4, version1.1-21; Bates et al., 2015), the random effects structure will be iteratively reduced starting with the random effect accounting for the smallest share of variance (Baayen et al., 2008;Barr et al., 2013). For this and all following tasks, analyses of binary outcome measures (i.e., choice in Reward Pairs and Unrewarded Habit tasks) will be conducted as binomial GLMMs. Where the dependent variable is continuous (i.e., ratings, log-transformed RTs), we will fit an LMM. All (G)LMMs will be bootstrapped to estimate confidence intervals for the regression coefficients and all predictor variables that are not categorical will be scaled so that each variable has a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one to enable comparisons of the size of their respective regression coefficients.
The level of statistical significance for all frequentist analyses will be set to α=.05, two-tailed, unless stated otherwise. All bootstrapped analyses will be based on 1,000 draws.
The Supplementary Information comprises the (G)LMMs described in the following sections with the pilot data to showcase these analyses.

div.head: RQ1: Does a frequency-based habitization process exist?
div.p: Choices. For the Reward Pairs task data, we will use a GLMM to analyze trial-wise left vs. right choice. Included predictors of choices are the difference in the values of the left and right stimuli (fixed effect, continuous) and the difference in previous choice frequency (fixed effect, continuous). We do not expect these effects to interact but will explore their interaction because it may be relevant for future research on addiction. In analogy to value, we assume that not the absolute choice frequency during training drives choice during test, but the relative frequency compared to the alternative option. We hypothesize that relative previous choice frequency predicts choice during test in addition to relative reward values.
Such a predictive relation would support a frequency-based habit process.

Response times. An LMM will be fit to RTs in the test phase. Specifically, logtransformed RTs are regressed on the value difference between the chosen and unchosen option (fixed effect, continuous), their difference in choice frequency during training (fixed effect, continuous), and the interaction of these effects. We use the difference between chosen and unchosen stimulus in RT analyses (in contrast to left vs. right in analyses of choices) to reduce the number of required regressors and simplify the analysis. If higher frequency of choice during training gives rise to stronger habits during test, then larger differences in choice frequency should be associated with faster responses as well. Hence, we hypothesize to find main effects of value and choice frequency difference, with faster responses for larger, positive differences. The main effect of previous choice frequency would again indicate frequency-based habitual behavior. In addition, we will include the score of the EHI as a covariate (fixed effect, continuous) in this analysis to control for generally faster responses with the preferred hand.

Stimulus ratings. An additional LMM will regress the ratings of the stimuli used in the Reward Pairs task after the test phase on the ratings before the training (fixed effect, continuous), the reward levels associated with the stimuli (fixed effect, ordinal), the relative choice frequency during training (fixed effect, continuous), and the interactions between these effects. If choice repetition enhances the subjective value of chosen stimuli, then post-study ratings should be higher for stimuli the participants chose more frequently during training than for stimuli they chose less frequently while controlling for pre-study ratings and reward value, that is, we hypothesize a statistically significant main effect of choice frequency during training.

Computational model parameters. We will fit the choice data with computational models, aiming to obtain a more detailed understanding of the mechanisms that underlie choices. The computational model consists of temporal difference reinforcement learning and a kernel capturing choice frequency (see Supplementary Information for details about the computational models) thus combining value-based reinforcement learning and frequencybased habit learning. To investigate whether frequency-based learning has a significant role for choices during training and test sessions, we will compare models including either reinforcement learning, a choice kernel, or both (or random choices independent of all kinds of stimulus values) with regard to their fit to the data. We hypothesize that model comparison and selection over the whole group based on the exceedance probability (Daunizeau et al., 2014;Rigoux et al., 2014;Stephan et al., 2009) will favor a model including the choice kernel for the training and test choice data over models without a choice kernel, which would support the assumption that a frequency-based habit process contributes to behavioral control in our task. In addition, we will explore model selection for individual participants based on the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC; Schwarz, 1978). For this, we use the criteria described by Raftery (1995) interpreting BIC differences of 6-10 as strong, and >10 as very strong evidence for the model with the smaller BIC. Thus, we do not assume that all participants necessarily adopt the same strategies in performing the task but might show interindividual differences. Moreover, we will explore the fit of additional models (e.g., rate correlation theory; Perez & Dickinson, 2020).

Participants with more than 50% missing trials in any training or test session will be excluded from these analyses. They will also be excluded from the analyses of the Reward Pairs task if they choose the worse of two stimuli during one training or the test session in at least 50% of trials. In addition, trials with RTs less than 50ms will be discarded, because such fast responses cannot be induced by perceived stimulus features.

div.head: RQ2: Is external reinforcement of behavior necessary for a frequency-based habitization or can the process arise also in a context without external reinforcement?
div.p: Choices. All choices made during the test phase will be modelled with a GLMM.

Specifically, left versus right choice is regressed on the relative frequency of making these choices during training (fixed effect, continuous) in a hierarchical binomial model. We hypothesize that relative choice frequency during training significantly predicts relative choice frequency in the test phase. Given that behavior in the Unrewarded Habit task is not reinforced, it may be more susceptible to researcher demand effects than the Reward Pairs task. To control for such effects, we include the mean score of the Social Desirability Scale (SDS-17;Stöber, 1999Stöber, , 2001; see Questionnaires) in the model as covariate of no interest (fixed effect, continuous) if the SDS-17 score will show a statistically significant correlation with choices. The covariate will be z-transformed (i.e., standardized) aiding convergence of the GLMM (Harrison et al., 2018) and making the corresponding regression coefficients interpretable as a standardized effect size (Schielzeth, 2010).

Response times. The log-transformed RTs in the test phase will be analyzed in an LMM as a function of previous choice frequency and stimulus presentation location. Thus, RTs are regressed on the stimulus presentation location of the chosen stimulus in relation to training (fixed effect, dichotomous, same vs. reversed location) and the difference in previous choice frequencies of the chosen and unchosen option (fixed effect, continuous). If a frequency-based habit has emerged, participants should respond faster in trials with the same stimulus presentation locations as in the training sessions compared to switched locations when choosing the stimulus with a higher choice frequency. Thus, we hypothesize that we observe an interaction between stimulus presentation location and previous choice frequency with fastest (slowest) RTs for presentations at the same (reversed) locations and high (low) previous choice frequency. Again, we will include the EHI score (fixed effect, continuous) in this analysis to control for effects of handedness on RTs.

Stimulus ratings. Another LMM will regress the ratings of the used stimuli after the test session on the ratings before trainings (fixed effect, continuous) and the relative choice frequency during training (fixed effect, continuous). Again, we hypothesize that the relative choice frequency affects post-training ratings, with higher ratings of the stimulus chosen more frequently during training compared to those stimuli chosen less frequently, while controlling for pre-training ratings.

Participants will be excluded from analyses with the Unrewarded Habits task if they fail to respond in more than 50% of trials in any training or test session or if they choose the wrong stimulus during one of the training sessions in 50% or more of the trials. In addition and similar to the Reward Pairs task, trials with RTs less than 50ms will be discarded.

div.head: RQ3: Is there a universal (i.e., paradigm independent) habitization process?
div.p: To analyze associations between experimental paradigms assessing habitual behavior, we will use the previously described scores of choices, RTs, stimulus ratings, and free parameters of computational models. The associations between the different paradigms will be investigated based on bootstrapped Pearson correlations and their bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals. In case of more than two scores (i.e., choices and RTs, Table S2), we will apply confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) to test whether a measurement model with one (Hypothesis 3.1) or two (Hypothesis 3.2) latent factors will fit the data. Model fit will be evaluated according to the criteria proposed by Schermelleh-Engel and colleagues (2003). In detail, we investigate the χ 2 goodness-of-fit statistic, Comparative Fit Index (CFI ≥ .95), Root
Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA ≤ .08), and Standardized Root Mean Square
Residual (SRMR ≤ .10). Comparison of different measurement models (Hypothesis 3.2) will be based on Satorra-Bentler-scaled χ 2 difference tests (i.e., non-significance indicates equal model fit).

For the analyses of Research Question 3 and the following Research Questions, we will impute missing data of the one task not performed by each participant (see Sampling plan) based on multivariate imputation by chained equations (van Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn, 2011). The imputation procedure takes advantage of the correlational patterns in the dataset, estimating the values of missing data for each participant several times. Since the proportion of missing values in one variable is maximally 50%, 50 imputed data sets will be created (White et al., 2011). The resulting statistical parameters of each data set (e.g., correlation coefficients) are pooled based on Rubin's (1987) rules to answer the Research Question.

div.head: RQ4: How does the habitization process relate to real-life habitual behavior?
div.p: Based on the measurement model investigated in Research Question 3, we will examine the association between the latent habitization process and self-reported habitual behavior according to the COHS, SHRI, and HTQ questionnaires. In case of just two available scores (i.e., stimulus ratings; computational parameters, see Table S2), the measurement model will be empirically under-identified and, therefore, we examine the association based on bootstrapped Pearson correlations and their bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals for each paradigm. In case of conflicting results regarding the association with the three questionnaires, the association with the SHRI will be regarded most valid.

div.head: RQ5: Is there a difference in validity with regard to various behavioral measures of habitual behavior?
div.p: To evaluate the hypotheses of the previous four Research Questions, it is sufficient if the results for at least one behavioral measure provide evidence for an effect of frequencybased behavior for each Research Question. However, to evaluate the validity of the different behavioral measures, we will examine the result pattern across all Research Questions with a focus on criterion validity (i.e., real-life habitual behavior; RQ4). If, for example, the results for RQ3 based on RTs and choices provide evidence for a universal habitization process but the results for RQ4 provide evidence for criterion validity only for RTs but not for choices, then RTs should be considered a more valid behavioral measure of habitual behavior than choices. As outlined above, we consider this Research Question as exploratory (and future research may want to revisit this question from a clinical perspective).

figure.figDesc: the instructed choice proportion of both stimuli is 50%. Stimuli are shown left and right of the center of the screen. To reduce cognitive demand and maximize the stability of the task environment, the presentation location of each stimulus remains fixed within but varies across participants. Participants complete one training session on each day. Each training session consists of six blocks of 20 trials for each of the two stimulus pairs, amounting to 600 training trials per pair.The test phase (Figure 1D) follows immediately after the fifth training session. During the test phase, we first present ten trials of each of the two trained stimulus pairs in the same presentation locations as during training. Then each of the four stimuli is presented with each other stimulus four times with balanced presentation locations of stimuli. These trials are randomly interspersed with an additional ten trials of each of the trained stimulus pairs where stimuli appear in switched locations compared to training. Starting with the same stimulus pairs and presentation locations aims at postponing the cognitive conflict participants might experience when stimuli are paired with other stimuli than during training or when locations are switched, which might in turn lead them to invest cognitive control masking habitual responding. The instructions inform participants to choose one of the two presented stimuli intuitively. Neither should they think much about the choice nor should they decide which button to press before the stimuli appear. They have to decide within a response time window of 500ms to limit the elaboration of decision strategies and facilitate the expression of potential habitual responses. With no obvious values guiding choice, we could expect random choices or simple choice strategies like alternating response sides irrespective of the presented stimuli. Alternatively, participants could have developed a preference for previously more frequently chosen stimuli over less frequently chosen stimuli, which would reflect the development of a habit induced by choice frequency. Similar to the procedure in the Rewarded Pairs task, participants perform the same test phase before the very first training session as simple check for pre-existing sensory preferences and to allow investigating training-induced changes in choices. The test phase is followed by a second stimulus rating. The outcome measures of interest are the observed choice frequencies and RTs during the test phase and the change of liking of the stimuli from the rating before training to the rating after the test phase as a function of the previous choice frequency during training. A frequency-based habit would decrease RTs and increase preferences and liking ratings for more frequently chosen stimuli. Similar to the Reward Pairs task, we will compute an individual score of frequencybased habitual choices during test (Unrewarded Habit choice score) capturing the relative preference for the more frequently chosen stimulus during training over the less frequently chosen stimulus. Positive Unrewarded Habit choice scores correspond to a preference for the previously more frequently chosen stimulus, scores around zero reflect no preference, and negative scores represent a preference for the less frequently chosen stimulus. figure.figDesc: The trial sequence of the test phase immediately after the fifth training session is similar to the training phase: each trial starts with the presentation of two stimuli, giving participants 800ms to make a selection via button press. Left and right presentation is balanced for each stimulus within participants. The chosen stimulus is framed for 500ms. The reward is not shown to prevent further learning. Each stimulus is presented with each other stimulus four times. Together with an additional eight trials for each of the three same-reward pairs, the test phase comprises 136 trials. The remainder of the response window is again added to the ITI to keep the duration of each trial constant. During the initial stimulus assessment phase before the first training session, i.e., before any stimulus is associated with any value information, participants perform the same session. Participants are just instructed to intuitively select the stimulus more appealing to them and to get used to the brief RT window without their choices having any consequences. With this procedure, we can test whether value and frequency differences experienced in training affect choices.Note that the test phase presents the stimuli of the same-reward pairs together for the first time since participants associated them with reward. Both stimuli of the same-reward pairs should have identical cached values after the prolonged training and based on value participants should be indifferent between them. However, if habitual behavior can develop from repeating one action more often, then stimuli chosen more frequently during training should be preferred during test. Between 248 and 424 points can be earned in the test phase.

The outcome measures of interest are the observed choice frequencies and RTs during the test phase and the change of the liking ratings from before the training to after the test phase. A frequency-based habit supposedly acquired during training would decrease RTs and increase preferences for, and ratings of, more frequently chosen stimuli. In addition, computational models of choices during the training and test phases including a choice kernel (see Analysis plan) should be favored over models based solely on the reinforcement value of stimuli or random choices. With this, we deviate from the traditional approach of using these direct tests might be too salient for many human participants. Instead, we test the potential effect of choice frequency during training on behavior during test. The circle is presented with the square in ten trials and with the triangle in 30 trials during training.Thus, stimuli of the same reward level (e.g., 5 points) will be chosen with different frequencies (e.g., 30 times for the pentagon and ten times for the circle ) for reward maximizing decision makers. C Trial sequence of the training phase of the Unrewarded Habit task. Each trial of the training phase starts with the presentation of two stimuli. A blue frame appears around one of the stimuli instructing participants to select this stimulus. A brown frame indicates both the chosen and unchosen stimulus. During the exponentially jittered inter-trial-interval, which also includes the remainder of the response time window, a fixation cross is presented in the center of the screen. D Test phase of the Unrewarded Habit task. Trials follow a similar sequence as the training trials but lack the blue frame to instruct participants which stimulus to choose. Thus, when the two stimuli appear on the screen, participants select one of them freely. RT -response time.

Reward pairs [A, B] and Unrewarded Habit [C, D] tasks. A Trial sequence of the training phase of the Reward Pairs task. Each trial starts with the presentation of two stimuli. The selected stimulus is indicated by a purple frame. Then both stimuli and their respective rewards are shown. A fixation cross is presented in the center of the screen during the exponentially jittered inter-trial-interval, which also includes the remainder of the response time window. The trial sequence and timing of the test phase (not shown) is similar but does not display the rewards. B Example stimulus-to-reward assignment of the Reward Pairs task, showing eight stimuli (geometric shapes), five reward levels (1, 3, 5, 7, and 9 points; yellow points), and the respective number of training trials per training session. For example, the pentagon and circle are both worth five points, while the triangle is worth seven points.
